title: 820-00923 - Does't see SSD
message:
Never even seen one of these before. No idea where to start.

Customer said liquid damage but I can't see any evidence.

Where do I start with this one?

title: 820-00923 - Does't see SSD
message:
Sees the SSD now.

Not sure what I changed. Must have a magic touch today.


Thanks.

title: 820-00923 - Does't see SSD
message: I don't have the diagram for this in front of me. If it has PICCOLO there is an issue where when PICCOLO goes bad it will not see the SSD below a certain battery percentage, typically 30%. Try again when you drain the battery. If you bring it down to 5-10%, can you reboot the machine and boot into the OS on the SSD?

title: 820-00923 - Does't see SSD
message:
Thanks Louis.

I'll go test that in a little bit. This would unfortunately destroy my magic touch theory, as it was on charge while I was working on it.

title: 820-00923 - Does't see SSD
message:
Yeh, the SSD is there sometimes and not there other times.

Sometimes I can see it in the boot menu, other times not and sometimes it's in Disk Utils and sometimes not. :/

Charging up the battery to see if that changes anything.

title: 820-00923 - Does't see SSD
message:
I charged the battery to 100% and still no SSD.

Guess we're off for a board repair now.

title: 820-00923 - Does't see SSD
message: IF there are no signs of liquid you don't touch this, take it to Apple.

title: 820-00923 - Does't see SSD
message: Usually I would agree, except the customer already took it to Apple and said it had liquid damage.

title: 820-00923 - Does't see SSD
message:
R9340 gives me 2.7, J9600 is in place snuggly.

The machine was actually working just fine but showed no SSD when customer came to collect, which was the original issue.

Every time it boots I get told to select a wifi network so it can install a critical update, but it always fails.
Only way to boot is in safe mode.

Any suggestions?
